title: What happened to Japanese weapons after Japan’s surrender in WW2? - Quora
tags: Military History and Wars of Japan

response.answer_text: None of the Japanese weapons were of any use other then for atomic bomb targets during post war nuclear bomb tests. So the vast majority of them were used as scrap metal to be used in the rebuilding of Japan in the post war period. Much of the Japanese industrial production capacity had been the target of American bomber attacks most of the heavy machinery used to produce large weapons such as tanks, navel guns, battleships, aircraft carriers, or aircraft engines was used for it’s scrap value and not allowed to be refurbished into anything like their former uses. Unlike Germany there was not a great deal of post war technology transfer between defeated Japan and her allied victors. There was some germ and chemical weapons research and scientists that were taken by the Americans but very little else was deemed important. A group of physicists was sent to evaluate the Japanese nuclear science, and some specialists examined the Japan’s aircraft industry and explosives industry with most of those reports being classified but there is little evidence that much of interest was found.

My father told the story of collecting Japanese small arms, laying them out on the street and then having a bulldozer run over them several times. My father’s uncles never forgave him for not bringing some home. He did bring home an officer’s sword, which he received in surrender, but that’s another story.
